First=
: I take this post as a confession that in the previous threads about TDD 
=
vs. DBC you really didn't know what you were talking of, because if you wer=
e, 
you wouldn't ask such questions but instead respond to my posts on thes=
e 
threads to continue argueing for DBC. The reason for that is not so obvi=
ous 
to me. I think positive, so I don't think you're a troll, I think it w=
as your 
way to find out how DBC and TDD interact - just say something you'=
re not 
really convinced of yourself but hold that view to see what argumen=
ts are 
against it. Please, next time just ask for these arguments instead =
of 
behaving like a time sink.


Basically, mock objects are a certain sub =
group of dummy objects.
The whole field of dummy objects can be classified =
into three kinds:
1. Stub objects which replace the real objects but don't =
provide all 
funcionality.
2. Dummy objects which just replace the real obj=
ects.
3. Mock objects which are dummy objects or stub objects 
(This helpfu=
l classification is taken from "Unit Tests mit Java" by Johannes 
Link, a r=
eally good German book about Unit Testing for TDD in Java using 
JUnit and =
some extensions and tools)


Take java.sql.ResultSet as an example.
The rea=
l object would be an implementation of ResultSet provided by a JDBC 
Driver=
.
A Stub would be a ResultSet implementation that does not provide all feat=
ures 
of ResultSets.
A Dummy would be a ResultSet implementation that provi=
des all features of 
ResultSets but replaces the ResultSet of a JDBC driver=
 within the test 
because it is more convenient to test a class using a Res=
ultSet without a 
real database connection.
A Mock would be a Stub or more =
a Dummy which provides additional features like 
generating statistics abou=
t the usage of the ResultSet, which could be logged 
to a Logger (file, net=
work or whatsoever) when the .close() or .finalize() 
method is invoked, an=
d that way could tell wether
a) All rows of the ResultSet were iterated ove=
r
b) All columns of the ResultSet were read
c) The ResultSet was correctly =
closed or closing was omitted

While a Dummy would behave somewhat normal, =
since it's task is to just replace 
the real object, a Mock object could al=
so influence the test. The Mock 
ResultSet e.g. could be instructed to thro=
w an SQLException on the third 
invocation of next() to verify wether the C=
UT/OUT correctly deals with 
exceptions.


Now to your questions:
> Does th=
e framework has to provide mock objects for JUnit tests?
No, it's not requi=
red that the framework provides the mock objects. But it 
would be helpful.=

Today, most frameworks do not provide Dummies or Mocks. Some frameworks 
p=
rovide stubs, like "javax.swing.table.AbstractTableModel" for 
"javax.swing=
.table.TableModel".

> Is it possible to use Mock objects when using a ERP =
framework?
That depends on wether the framework deserves the name framework=
 or not.
A real framework consists of two parts: The API/SPI and the implem=
entation. If 
the framework is a real framework, you could simply implement=
 the API/SPI 
yourself to create mock objects and replace the implementatio=
n.

But your questions do not provide the information *where* and *why* you=
 want 
to use Mock objects. So you program using the ERP API yourself? Or i=
s it just 
a code generation tool like Versata?

Providing complete mock ob=
jects can be really elaborate. In most cases, you 
don't provide full featu=
red mock objects based on dummies, but mock objects 
based on stubs providi=
ng all required features.
